1.name: Mano Marks
1.title: Director, Developer Relations
1.shortBio: Mano is the Director of Developer Relations at Docker...
1.bio: A developer relations professional since 2006, I have extensive helping developers understand how to integration developer tools into their applications. I've worked in all ends of developer relations including support, content creation, one-to-many presentations, videos, partner support, blogging, social media, and technical writing. I'm focused now on building the Developer Relations program at Docker to be a world class team helping developers with the single hottest tech in the industry.

2.name: Chet Haase
2.title: Senior Staff Software Engineer
2.shortBio: Chet leads the team that works on UI, animations, graphics, and hardware acceleration for the Android platform...
2.bio: Leading/managing the team that works on UI, animations, graphics, and hardware acceleration for the Android platform. I also occasionally write animation and graphics code. And give presentations on how to do this stuff.

3.name: Romain Guy
3.title: Senior Staff Software Engineer
3.shortBio: Romain leads the Android Graphics team at Google...
3.bio: Manager/lead of the Android Graphics team at Google. The team is responsible for the lower layers of the graphics stack including Vulkan, OpenGL ES, SurfaceFlinger and Hardware Composer.  Prior to this, I was the tech lead/manager for the Android UI toolkit team. I wrote the OpenGL rendering pipeline used to hardware accelerate all Android applications. I've worked on Android since before its first public release and I have done many other things that are still in your phones and SDKs.

4.name: Wesley Chun
4.title: Senior Developer Advocate
4.shortBio: Wesley is a technical professional with over two decades of programming, writing, and teaching experience...
4.bio: Technical professional with over two decades of programming, writing, and teaching experience available for short-term and part-time consulting projects to help you design the right solution! We can tackle your Python project regardless of where it stands in the timeline, whether you need actual software engineering, design and architecture, or just to take a look at your existing Python code for meeting style guidelines, correctness, optimization, refactoring, etc. Need help defining structure and process (documentation [PRD/MRD, SRS/FS, DS/SDS], software lifecycle, and recommended tools [source control, issue tracking]) between your Engineering team and other organizations? We can help out with that too.

5.name: Paco Solsona
5.title: Developer Relations Regional Lead
5.shortBio: Paco is part of the the Google Developers Ecosystem team at Google...
5.bio: I am part of Google Developers Ecosystem team, and lead our community, mentors, and startup-related programs for Spanish-speaking LATAM. We foster one of the strongest and cohesive network of leaders, influencers, and partners in Latin America; and together we are helping developers, and startups thrive. From the many activities we support, the many Launchpad events across the region, to our flagship program Google Developers Launchpad Accelerator.

6.name: Jason Mayes (MEng, CIPT, MBCS)
6.title: Web Engineer - Creative Technologist
6.shortBio: Jason combines his knowledge of the technical and creative worlds to solve complex, strategic - technical challenges for Google...
6.bio: Jason combines his knowledge of the technical and creative worlds to solve complex, strategic - technical challenges for Google's largest customers and internal teams. Developing innovative world firsts utilizing the latest web technologies and hardware is a key component of his role where it is his responsibility to know something about everything that matters to rapidly prototype new ideas and solutions globally.  With a background in Computer Science at the University of Bristol, England, where he specialized in reality mining and invisible computing, Jason has been a 'hybrid engineer' for over 10 years. Combining his passion for several areas including both front and back end web programming, but also design and user experience, he has worked in many sizes of company from startups (including founding his own) to Google. As a mentor to many, he enjoys sharing his daily discoveries for all his curiosities online, which has attracted a global following of over 160,000.

11.shortBio: Murat is a GDE on Android and has been an active organizer from 2009 to last year when he moved to CA...

12.name: Masashi Katsumata
12.title: Web & Android Programmer
12.shortBio: Masashi is a broad-skilled software engineer with both client-side and server-side experience. He loves JavaScript (again for clients and servers), but he also use Java, Python, Objective-C, c++ and others....
12.bio: Masashi is a broad-skilled software engineer with both client-side and server-side experience. He loves JavaScript (again for clients and servers), but he also use Java, Python, Objective-C, c++ and others.  As a Google Developer Expert in Japan, Masashi has published three books on the subject of Google Maps API. He's also worked on projects that use Google Maps API(JavaScript) and Google App Engine(Python).  After working in Japan for seven years, Masashi moved to the USA, where he now works with Social Rewards, inc. Here, he's in charge of developing a photo booth which displays real-time composite pictures using Android (Java, and c++) and OpenCV(c++).

13.name: Justin Ribeiro
13.title: Web & Android Programmer
13.shortBio: Justin is the CEO of Stickman Ventures, a Software Development and Technology Service firm...
13.bio: Justin is the CEO of Stickman Ventures, a Software Development and Technology Service firm.  He also is a Google Developer Expert and leading speaker on Internet of Things.

14.name: James Cha
14.title: Developer Advocate
14.shortBio: James is a developer advocate at Clover Networks, the worlds most hackable cash register...
14.bio: James is a software developer by trade and a firm believer in community and does his part in encouraging and supporting its growth.  He is a developer community activist organizing events and leading meetings.   He has had the opportunity to organize meetings that have 10 - 20 attendees and also organize events that have over 350 attendees.  From his involvement in the community he has been able to use the resources to work with schools to teach and mentor students as young as elementary school to get into coding.   He has lead workshops and also taught at community college.

18.name: Bethany Fong
18.title: Senior Interaction Designer
18.shortBio: Bethany is a senior interaction designer on the Material Design team at Google...
18.bio: Bethany is a senior interaction designer on the Material Design team at Google. During her 5+ years at Google, she's worked on Android TV, Android OS, Android Accessibility, and contributed to the foundation for the Material Design language. See her team's work at www.material.io. Bethany is a proud alumna of the Stanford Product Design program.

19.name: Dr. Wes Boudville
19.title: Co-founder, Chief Science Officer
19.shortBio: Dr. Wesley Boudville is co-founder and Chief Science Officer of MetaSwarm, Inc. Dr. Boudville is one of the youngest PhD Computational Physics graduates from CalTech.
19.bio: Dr. Boudville is co-inventor of over 34 patents pending that provide the basis for the MetaSwarm Product Suite for safeguarding Internet communications, including anti-spam and anti-phishing technologies.

20.name: Ayman Mahfouz
20.title: VP, Engineering
20.shortBio: Software was my passion long before it became my profession. I got my first computer back in 5th grade and I was hooked to that 64K RAM Z80...
20.bio: Software was my passion long before it became my profession. I got my first computer back in 5th grade and I was hooked to that 64K RAM Z80! I wrote my first programs in BASIC and became fond of writing games through high school.  I decided to study CS to build a solid foundation for my hobby. During college, I won a couple of programming awards including a national one for a billirads game I wrote in C++. Then, I had some of my games selected for commercial release by a software firm. Since graduating, I have been building enterprise software on various technology stacks, albeit primarily using Java. Recently, I have been focusing on enterprise mobility and IoT.  Over the years, I have used a dozen programming languages. I take a lot of pride in my code. I always look for ways to improve architecture and means to refactor code to make it clean and elegant.  Gradually, as I advanced in my career to senior then principal engineer then to principal then chief architect, I found myself becoming the default go-to person for whatever team I worked in. Not necessarily because my technical knowledge was needed, but also because my judgement was required. I always liked working closely with others and think I have the talent of getting people to work together as a team. This culminated in my appointment as VP of Engineering at Webalo. My style of management is very people-oriented. I believe that development process should be flexible to bring the best out of every individual.  My management role exposed me to new experiences including competitive analysis, product management, business development, customer management, and other aspects that complete the cycle of taking a vision and producing code that realizes it. Although now I am in management, I still keep my hands dirty as much as I can. When I can't manage to spend enough time coding at work, I log on to hackerrank to solve a programming challenge, learning new languages along the way.
